course_name: Media Technology and City Design and Development
course_description:
This workshop explores the potential of media technology and the Internet to enhance communication and transform city design and community development in inner-city neighborhoods. The class introduces a variety of methods for describing or representing a place and its residents, for simulating actions and changes, for presenting visions of the future, and for engaging multiple actors in the process of envisioning change and guiding action. Students will engage two neighborhoods: the Mill Creek neighborhood of West Philadelphia, PA, and the Brightwood/Northend neighborhood of Springfield, MA. Students will meet real people working on real projects, put theory into practice, and reflect on insights gained in the process. Our hope is that student work will contribute to new initiatives in both communities.
The class Web site can be found here: Media Technology and City Design and Development. It is sponsored by the West Philadelphia Landscape Project and the Center for Reflective Community Practice.
syllabus_content:
Course Description

This workshop explores the potential of media technology and the Internet to enhance communication and transform city design and community development in inner-city neighborhoods. The class introduces a variety of methods for describing or representing a place and its residents, for simulating actions and changes, for presenting visions of the future, and for engaging multiple actors in the process of envisioning change and guiding action. Students will engage two neighborhoods, meet real people working on real projects, put theory into practice, and reflect on insights gained in the process. Our hope is that student work will contribute to new initiatives in both communities.

Within this context of media technology, a major theme will be the transfer of knowledge from a fifteen-year old university-community partnership in Philadelphia, the West Philadelphia Landscape Project (
WPLP
). This will entail both a re-presentation of knowledge to those currently living in or working in West Philadelphia and a presentation of lessons from WPLP relevant to other university-community partnerships, such as the recent partnership between MIT and Springfield. The integration of comprehensive, top-down approaches and grassroots, bottom-up approaches to urban design and planning is another major theme. A third theme is how different types of languages (e.g. professional and vernacular, verbal and visual, English and Spanish) facilitate and impede thinking and communicating about alternatives for city planning and design.

Places

There are two sites for the course of the semester: the Mill Creek neighborhood of West Philadelphia, PA and the Brightwood/Northend neighborhood of Springfield, MA. Mill Creek is a neighborhood whose population is African-American; Brightwood/Northend is predominantly Puerto-Rican. The population of each neighborhood is both low-income and middle-class. There will be a weekend field trip to each, one to Philadelphia in February and one to Springfield in March.

Background

The City of Philadelphia recently received a Hope VI grant to redevelop Mill Creek Public Housing, originally designed by architect Louis Kahn, in a collaboration between the Philadelphia Housing Authority, Philadelphia Water Department, and the community. Many of the ideas underlying the City's proposal were developed by WPLP in collaboration with neighborhood residents and teachers and students in a local middle-school. How can the knowledge and visions produced by these earlier efforts serve as a resource for these new ventures and be effectively communicated to new actors, such as city officials and professional consultants they hire?

The Brightwood/Northend neighborhood of Springfield is embarking on an ambitious program of community planning and development, for which they have good support from city agencies. What can Springfield learn from the 15-year experience of WPLP, its successes and failures, and how can this knowledge be transferred?

Website Proposal
Audience:
The audience for this proposed website is the interested members of the Mill Creek community, which includes
not only residents, but also those people connected to the area relationally, professionally, and commercially. Yet
the site should be accessible and understandable for other people outside the community who want to know
about Mill Creek and the West Philadelphia Landscape Project. The active site of the Mill Creek neighborhood
will be of interest to the secondary audience (other organized community groups like NEON, professionals and
academics like ourselves). The West Philadelphia Landscape Project component of the website, however, will be
directed more specifically for this secondary audience.
Ownership/
Maintenance:
The subject of ownership, maintenance, and possibly hosting of this website ought to be discussed with the Mill
Creek community members. Based on conversations and feelings gathered from the visit to West Philadelphia in
February, I would suggest a partnership between the Mill Creek Coalition and students at Sulzberger Middle
School in owning and maintaining the Mill Creek site, as well as the WPLP component. As current members of
the Mill Creek community, these groups would best serve as the administrators to an active website about the
Mill Creek neighborhood, and they seem to be the ones most enthusiastic about having ownership of such a
website. Specific content should be decided by the Mill Creek Coalition and the students at Sulzberger. The hope
is that the content would reflect not only these institutions but also those of other community interests.
Investigating these other interests may rest upon the coalition and students who take up the administration of the
website.
Purpose:
The website will be a space where the Mill Creek community members can represent their neighborhood to
themselves and to other communities. A part of the website will serve as an updated "newsletter" of sorts to the
different organizations featured in the West Philadelphia Landscape Project based in Mill Creek (i.e. Mill Creek
Coalition, Sulzberger Middle School, community gardens in West Philly, etc.). These will serve as homepages
for the various groups, which they can update frequently as different news and activities arise for their group.
These will all be linked from the main Mill Creek homepage. (See structure section). In the long run, I think it
would be neat to have an emailable newsletter drawing interested members of the community to the website for
more information. (Similar to the emailed headlines feature of the New York Times for example). These can be
sent out every month or every two weeks on a regular basis to bring people interested in the Mill Creek
neighborhood and its activities to the website for updated news.
The stories section can host a variety of stories from individual Mill Creek community members. A link will be
directed to the stories of the WPLP which will be placed in the WPLP section. The general stories section of the
Mill Creek site, however, will be a place for any story relevant to the neighborhood. The stories of the Mill Creek
site can be anything from the community, not necessarily related to the watershed or the public activism. I think
this would be a neat place for other voices in the neighborhood to emerge. Other issues pertinent to the
community may be raised in this manner, and perhaps will lead to dialog.
The WPLP part of the website will serve more as an archival section, which can be updated as needed. Based on
Jeff Scaveron's suggestion, an important part of this section will be stories from people and/or about places in
Mill Creek and "events" of the WPLP. Whether the subject is about a person/role, an object, place, or event, the
story should be a personal account. First-person points of view are so much more compelling. Also, other parts
of the WPLP section will have descriptive documents and histories so the "third-person" story of the WPLP is
being presented in a way. This other material should be well-structured and organized for easy browsing,
searching, and clarity. Perhaps multiple "browse by" or "search by" options would be helpful, i.e. browse/search
by chronology, medium, specific project, issue, agency, etc.

Content:
G overview of the website, brief description of its origins, the WPLP and Mill Creek
G homepages for the Mill Creek Coalition, Sulzberger Middle School, Aspen Farms (or a collection of all
the community gardens?)
G stories from the community, about anything, with a link to WPLP specific stories
G archives from the WPLP

information on the WPLP

H description of partners and affiliates (U Penn, Water Dept., EPA, etc.)
H documents
H database
